title: 104_hr3399
content:
The International Development Association Act is amended to authorize $550,000,000 for the United States contribution to the tenth replenishment of resources. The African Development Bank Act is amended to authorize the United States to subscribe to additional shares of the bank's capital stock, with appropriations required for payment. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act is amended to include a new section regarding contributions to the interest subsidy account of the successor (ESAF II) to the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility of the International Monetary Fund. The United States Governor of the Fund may contribute $75,000,000 to the Interest Subsidy Account of the Successor (ESAF II) to the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility of the Fund. This contribution is subject to appropriations Acts and there is an authorization of $75,000,000 without fiscal year limitation for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury. TITLE IV--MIDDLE EAST DEVELOPMENT BANK

Sec. 401. This title may be cited as the ``Bank for Economic Cooperation and Development in the Middle East and North Africa Act''.

Sec. 402. The President is authorized to accept membership for the United States in the Bank for Economic Cooperation and Development in the Middle East and North Africa (the ``Bank'') as per the Agreement. The Governor and Alternate Governor of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development are appointed under the Bretton Woods Agreements Act. The President appoints a Governor and an alternate with Senate approval. No salary or compensation is provided for these roles. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act applies to the Bank in the same way as to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund. Federal Reserve banks can serve as depositories or fiscal agents for the Bank, with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System overseeing these functions. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to subscribe on behalf of the United States for up to 7,011,270 shares of the capital stock of the Bank, with an appropriation of $1,050,007,800. Any income distribution from the Bank to the United States shall be deposited into the Treasury. This section also addresses the jurisdiction of United States courts and the enforcement of arbitral awards. The Bank, for civil actions in the US, territories, or Puerto Rico, is deemed an inhabitant of the district where its office is located. US district courts have jurisdiction over actions involving the Bank. The Bank can remove actions from State courts to the appropriate district. The Bank can remove actions from State courts to the appropriate district court of the United States by following the procedure in section 1446 of title 28, United States Code. The Agreement will be in full force in the US, its territories, and Puerto Rico upon US membership in the Bank. Certain securities issued by the Bank are exempt from securities laws, and reports are required. Sec. 409 amends a section of the Revised Statutes by including the Bank for Economic Cooperation and Development in the Middle East and North Africa. Securities issued by the Bank are exempt from certain securities laws, and reports must be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities and Exchange Commission can require annual reports on securities issued by the Bank for Economic Cooperation and Development in the Middle East and North Africa. The Commission has the authority to suspend certain provisions regarding these securities and must report to Congress on the operation of this section. Sec. 410 amends the International Financial Institutions Act and Public Law 91-599 to include the Bank for Economic Cooperation and Development in the Middle East and North Africa in certain provisions.
